title: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Evaluation of the Safety and Efficacy of Memantine in Non-Institutionalized Agitated Patients With Moderate to Severe Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: About 65% of patients with severe Alzheimer's Disease (AD) will have symptoms of agitation. There are drawbacks associated with the currently available therapeutic interventions for agitation associated with Alzheimer's Disease. In a recent trial, in the group of patients with moderate to severe AD treated with memantine, there were fewer incidences of agitation. It is hypothesized that memantine will be effective in reducing the symptoms of agitation associated with moderate to severe Alzheimer's Disease.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests memantine to reduce agitation (a behavioral/neuropsychiatric symptom) in moderate–to–severe Alzheimer’s disease. Memantine is a small‑molecule NMDA receptor antagonist approved for moderate–to–severe AD; its mechanism and indication are described in the prescribing information. citeturn1search0turn0search2
